deck: The Kuril Islands, are a archipelago claimed by Sakhalin Oblast, Russia and Hokkaido Prefecture, Japan
description: Disputed islands between Japan and Russia. Prior to World War II Japan possessed the islands, but the Soviet Union took control over the islands after World War II.
name: Kuril Islands

deck: The Sakha Republic is a federal Republic of Russia.  Eighth largest territory in the world, is larger than Argentina and just smaller than India.  Its capital is the city of Yakutsk. Sakha is known for its climate extremes, being the coldest area in the northern hemisphere. Winters here are extremely cold. Some of the lowest natural temperatures ever recorded have been here.
name: Sakha (Yakutia) Republic

deck: The Kamchatka Peninsula is a peninsula in the Russian Far East.  It is a federal subject of Russia, formed on July 1 2007.
name: Kamchatka Krai

deck: Big Star City is the main location in Black Star Fiction Library's comic book titles. The fictional city is home to corrupt politicians, a crooked police force, and dangerous, violent criminals.
description:
Description

Big Star City is a 22nd century dystopian metropolis, a run-down city where the rain is seemingly constant, and the only colour in the landscape comes from the hundreds of crass neon signs and billboards. It is a place rife with chaos and despair, where the worst of humanity can be found.

Among the more noteworthy Big Star City inhabitants are:

  • Scratch - Scratch is a serial killer who lives in Big Star City. He is the protagonist of Black Star Fiction. He has a very dark sense of humour, and seems at home among the criminals and degenerates of Big Star City
  • Carlos Mendosa - A reporter who is determined to catch the serial killer who is stalking the streets of Big Star City.
  • Lieutenant Enrico Santos - A high ranking but deeply corrupt officer of Big Star City Police Department.

Notable Locations

The city skyline is dominated by neon signs and advertisements for local and global businesses. The most notable of which include:

  • Texaco Hygiene
  • Skin Stripper
  • Andy Disney
  • Chrysler Express
  • Global Dream Industries
  • Vicious Burger

issue_credits.name: "...and they shall know my name by the trail of dead..."

name: Big Star City

deck: The Gibborim's "Realm of Slumber" was apparently an abyss from which the Gibborim emerged when summoned, a great pit surrounded by rocky cliffs or bluffs. deck: A parallel dimension which features heavily in the Razorline title Ectokid. It is populated with ghosts, imps and other supernatural creatures.
description:
Background

The Ectosphere and it's ghoulish inhabitants are usually imperceptible to humans. One of the few people who can see into the realm is teenager Dexter Mungo, a boy whose mother was a clairvoyant adept at summoning spirits from the Ectosphere. One of the spirits impregnates her, and Dexter (otherwise known as Ectokid) is born. Because of his odd parentage, he has an unusual ability. He can only see the real world through one eye - and through the other, he sees the Ectosphere.

first_appeared_in_issue.name: Chase, A Tale of the Barkerverse

issue_credits.name: Chase, A Tale of the Barkerverse

deck: The Harbinger Foundation is primarily a secret school submerged deep inside Harada Global Conglomerates. They also function as the private special security arm for the entire Harada Organization. The foundation was moved to Pittsburgh to accommodate the addition of Peter Stanchek.
description:
There are 3 types of people in the world. The majority of the world would be considered Norms, some intuitive, some not. Those that have a gifted ability locked inside them would be called Latents. They are very rare. And the rarest of people are those born 'Activated'. To be 'Activated', means the individual has access to their special, extraordinary ability that gives them powers beyond the Norms of the world. The process is painful, humbling, and dangerous. At the Harbinger Foundation, once a student is 'Activated', they begin 3 years of total immersion training. Each student wears a different uniform that signifies their year in the program:

  • 1st Year - Ichinensei
  • 2nd Year - Nensei
  • 3rd Year - Shinia
name: Harada Conglomerates

deck: Setting for BBC stop-motion puppet show and its comic spin-offs.
description: Camberwick Green was the setting for a children's puppet show of the same name, which debuted on 3rd March 1966 on BBC 1. Despite only lasting one series of thirteen episodes, it spawned two follow-on shows, Trumpton and Chigley (the latter a village near Camberwick Green). Though together all three shows only accrued three years and 39 episodes, it was frequently repeated into the 1970s, and ten Camberwick Green Annuals were published between 1967 and 1976. Chigley had two annuals (1970 and 1971), while Trumpton had eight (1967 to 1974). All three series also had strips in Polystyle's Pippin in Playland. It remains such a British icon of the era that the TV show Life on Mars, where an modern day police officer apparently finds himself thrown back into the early 1970s, pastiched the opening sequence in one episode.
name: Camberwick Green

deck: Fully functional life-size clockwork solar system.
description:
Created by writer Ian Edginton with artists D'Israeli and I.N.J.Culbard, The Orrery appears in the 2000AD series 'Brass Sun'.

The Orrery is a clutch of planets, moons and asteroids orbiting a vast life-giving Brass Sun via immense metal spars, its origin and purpose long since forgotten.

The once unified collection of worlds have regressed into eccentric fiefdoms and petty baronies. One such planet, 'Hind Leg', is ruled by religious dogma - it's rulers (led by Lord Archimandrite) believe the Cog is Creation, and any suggestion that the sun is slowing is treated as heresy.

But for many, including Wren and Cadwallader, there's no escaping the truth that worlds are dying and something needs to be done before the ice claims all...
name: The Orrery

deck: Lunar base that survived the Moon being blasted out of Earth's orbit and into interstellar space.
description:
Moonbase Alpha was the main setting for the TV series Space 1999, the story of the inhabitants of a lunar base that survives the Moon being blasted out of orbit after nuclear waste dumped on the Moon's dark side detonates, sending the satellite hurtling into interstellar space.

The television show Space 1999 was created by Gerry Anderson for ITC Entertainment. Initially intended as a second season of the Anderson's UFO show, Anderson was asked by ITC head Sir Lew Grade to set the new season mostly on the moonbase shown in UFO, which ratings suggested had been popular with viewers. Over time the concept grew and morphed until it became a brand new show. It began airing on 4th September 1975; the same week a tie-in comic strip began in Look-In Magazine. At ITC's insistence, the TV show had two American leads, married couple Martin Landau and Barbara Bain, in an effort to make it more saleable overseas, and in November 1975 Charlton began publication of both a US tie-in comic and a magazine.

Fictional history

Earth's Space Research Centre on the Moon, Moonbase Alpha, began construction in 1983 in the crater Plato, and, despite a hiatus necessitated by the outbreak of world war in 1987, was eventually completed in 1997. In 1999 Commander John Koenig took over command from Anton Gorski, but a couple of months later, in August, the Moon was unexpectedly fired out of orbit when a nuclear waste dump on the far side from Alpha reached critical mass and detonated. Perhaps influenced by unknown extraterrestrial parties, the Moon transited interstellar distances in mere weeks, with the 311 inhabitants of Alpha now nomads looking for a new home.
name: Moonbase Alpha

deck: An upside down version of Metropolis, hidden within an extra-dimensional fourth cloud floating aboe Metropolis.
description:
Located in the extra-dimensional fourth cloud, in the sky above Metropolis, rests a upside down version of Metropolis - dubbed "Untropolis".

Untropolis spontaneously formed nearly five years ago - which Father Time, of S.H.A.D.E., points out happened around the same time as the Time-Sniper incident (which is classified).

S.H.A.D.E. has a field office in Untropolis, where Frankenstein and his group the creature commandos were sent to, to try and uncover a mole in their organization.

The only way to enter Untropolis is to use Cloud-Packs, which are one-time use for entrance and exiting the cloud. Without the cloud-packs, and the nether-field is creates, you would be vaporized instantly - upon contact with the cloud-dimensional membrane.

Everything in Untropolis is upside down. From the buildings, to the people in the society; an example being that the impoverished live in penthouse suites.

Finding their target among the Untropolis populous is no easy task for Frankenstein and his team. Scarab Agents are brought in by their target, Crowly, to evade capture.

deck: Concealed base for the Mys-Tech corporation.
description:
Mys-Tech buit a concealed base beneath one of their public organisations, The Museum of Pagan Antiquities in London, in the form of underground headquarters. In the base the organisation housed arcane magical technologies, biotech labs.

The headquarters were also the base for the mercenaries working for the Mys-Tech, who travelled through space and dimensions to steal technology for their employers.

deck: Home planet of the Araknoids.
description:
Planet inhabited by aracnid beings with 8 limbs.

At the core of the planet is located the Nucleolus, a living mind axis composed of the ancienmost threads of crystalline web and said to contain the souls of the ancient Araknoids.

On this planet there is also a spider version of the Knights of Pendragon, whose last living paladin is Arrakhyl.

Other characters from this planet are:

  • Malekyth
  • Rikskath
  • Tanakyth
name: Arakne

deck: a.k.a. Mega-City Three, the third of the former U.S.A.'s post-apocalypse metropolises in the Judge Dredd series.
description: Formerly known as Mega-City Three prior to the Civil War between the Mega-Cities of 2083-2086. Though Texas City was mentioned and its Judges were first seen back during the Luna City storylines of Prog 42 to 58, Texas City itself was not seen until Judge Dredd's hunt for the Judge Child took him there in Prog 160. Known citizens include Pa Angel, until his crimes forced him to flee the city and raise his unholy brood of malevolent sons in the Cursed Earth, and Texas City judges include Judge Tex, who served with Dredd on Luna City, and Judge Cain, who quit to become Preacher Cain, a.k.a. the Missionary Man.

deck: The sometimes headquarters to the Thunderbolts.
description:
Thunderbolts tower was originally built in New York at Four Freedoms Plaza. After the team were exposed as the Masters of Evil, they were forced to abandon their headquarters in New York.

It was recently rebuilt on The Raft prison and the basement served as a habitat for Man-Thing. The tower, alongside the Thunderbolts, became unstuck in time and the Tower travelled to different locations and periods in time including Austria and London.
